Description: Medical device manufacturer ev3 Inc., formerly known as Fox Hollow Technologies Inc., agreed to pay the United States $1.25 million to resolve allegations under the False Claims Act that Fox Hollow caused certain hospitals to submit false claims to Medicare for unnecessary inpatient admissions related to minimally-invasive atherectomy procedures.
Covidien LP paid $13 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations resulting from its alleged payment of kickbacks in connection with sales of its Solitaire mechanical thrombectomy device.

Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on February 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data was a spreadsheet version of information contained in individual case documents that can be retrieved at https://www.ahs.dep.pa.gov/eFACTSWeb/default.aspx

Description: Medtronic plc and affiliated Medtronic companies -- Medtronic Inc., Medtronic USA Inc., and Medtronic Sofamor Danek USA Inc. -- agreed to pay $4.41 million to the United States to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by making false statements to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and the U.S. Department of Defense regarding the country of origin of certain Medtronic products sold to the United States.
Medtronic Inc. agreed to pay the United States $40 million to settle civil allegations that its Medtronic Sofamor Danek division paid kickbacks to doctors to induce them to use its spinal products.

Medtronic Inc. of Fridley, Minn., agreed to pay $23.5 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claim Act by using physician payments related to post-market studies and device registries as kickbacks to induce doctors to implant the company's pacemakers and defibrillators.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Description: Medtronic Inc., of Fridley, Minnesota, agreed to pay $9.9 million to resolve allegations under the False Claims Act that the company used various types of payments to induce physicians to implant pacemakers and defibrillators manufactured and sold by Medtronic.

Medical device manufacturer Medtronic Inc. agreed to pay the United States $2.8 million to resolve allegations under the False Claims Act that Medtronic caused certain physicians to submit false claims to federal health care programs for a medical procedure known as SubQ stimulation.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Medtronic Interventional Vascular Inc. agreed to pay $290,000 to resolve OFCCP claims of pay discrimination affecting 78 Hispanic workers at the company's manufacturing facility in Danvers, Mass.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Medtronic Spine LLC, the corporate successor to Kyphon Inc., agreed to pay the United States $75 million to settle allegations that it caused the submission of false claims to Medicare.

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: hazardous materials shipping
Info Source: from a spreadsheet posted on the FAA website at https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ash/ash_programs/hazmat/compliance_enforcement/

Agency: Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on May 15, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Description: meal/rest break violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Van Ba Ma v. Covidien Holding Inc et al

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Minnesota-based medical device manufacturer ev3 Inc. agreed to plead guilty to charges that it distributed an adulterated version of its neurovascular medical device, Onyx Liquid Embolic System. As part of the criminal resolution, ev3 agreed to pay a criminal fine of $11.9 million and will forfeit $6 million.

Covidien LP agreed to pay $17,477,947 to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by providing free or discounted practice development and market development support to physicians located in California and Florida to induce purchases of Covidien's vein ablation products.

Medtronic agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by the attorneys general of New York, Oregon, Texas and California alleging that it improperly induced physicians to recommend Medtronic devices to treat cardiac rhythmic disease. This was part of a larger $9.9 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-medtronic-inc

Medtronic agreed to pay $327,000 to settle multistate allegations that it submitted claims for replacement insulin infusion pumps that were initiated through the improper solicitation of Medicaid recipients. This was part of a larger $2.8 million settlement involving the federal government.
Info Source: $2.8 Million Multi-state Settlement Reached with Medical Device Manufacturer, Targeted News Service, June 30, 2015 (via Nexis).

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Medtronic Sofamor Danek agreed to pay $12 million to five states -- California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Oregon and Washington -- to resolve allegations that the company misled consumers about the safety of a bone graft device.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Medtronic Inc. agreed to pay $5.8 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that its Medtronic Sofamor Danek division paid kickbacks to doctors to induce them to use its spinal products, thus causing the submission of false claims to state Medicaid programs. This was part of a larger $40 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-medtronic-inc-2

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: disability discrimination

Minnesota-based medical device maker Medtronic USA Inc. agreed to pay $8.1 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks to induce a South Dakota neurosurgeon to use certain Medtronic products.

Agency: Connecticut Department of Energy & Environmental Protection
Notes: Captured from summaries produced by DEP; may not include full details of penalties.

Description: Medtronic announced that it would pay $22 million to settle 950 lawsuits alleging complications from INFUSE Bond Graft products.
Medtronic disclosed that it had taken a $278 million charge to cover the cost of settling multi-district litigation relating to defective Sprint Fidelis defibrillation leads.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Medtronic, Inc., Sprint Fidelis Leads Products Liability Litigation

Description: Medtronic agreed to pay $400,000 to resolve the state's share of Medicaid damages in allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks to induce a South Dakota neurosurgeon to use certain Medtronic products.
